required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Safety and Efficacy of a Novel Carpal Tunnel Tissue Manipulation Device in Treating Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
clinical_study.official_title: Safety and Efficacy of a Novel Carpal Tunnel Tissue Manipulation Device in Treating Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

brief_summary.textblock: A single-center, prospective, non-randomized study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a novel carpal tunnel tissue manipulation device in treating symptoms and decreased physical function in subjects previously diagnosed with mild to severe carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

detailed_description.textblock: A single-center, prospective, non-randomized study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a novel carpal tunnel tissue manipulation device in treating symptoms and decreased physical function in subjects previously diagnosed with mild to severe carpal tunnel syndrome.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in SSS of the BCTQ at 28 Days vs Baseline
primary_outcome.description: The primary efficacy variable is the decrease in Symptom Severity Scale (SSS) score of the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ). The SSS is a patient-reported measure of the severity of the patient's symptoms caused by carpal tunnel syndrome, on a scale of 1 (no symptoms) to 5 (worst symptoms).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in SSS of the BCTQ 2 Month Post-treatment vs Baseline
secondary_outcome.description: The secondary efficacy variable is the decrease in Symptoms Severity Scale (SSS) score of the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ) obtained 2 months after the 28-day CTMD treatment period compared to the Baseline SSS score.

intervention.description: This piece of rigid, shaped, biocompatible plastic (polypropylene) rated for skin contact and a strong but safe hypoallergenic biocompatible medical adhesive which bonds the skin over the carpal tunnel to the plastic piece for a duration of 2-14 hours.

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Participants were only enrolled if a nerve conduction study (NCS) was performed at the enrollment visit or within the past 6 months, electrodiagnostically confirming the presence of mild to severe CTS.

group.title: Carpal Tunnel Medical Device (CTMD)
group.description: The Carpal Tunnel Tissue Manipulation Device (CTMD) is a piece of rigid, shaped, biocompatible plastic (polypropylene) rated for skin contact and a strong but safe hypoallergenic biocompatible medical adhesive which bonds the skin over the carpal tunnel to the plastic piece. The CTMD is worn for a duration of 8-10 hours daily over the treatment period. If a participant had bilateral CTS, both wrists were treated but only the worst wrist (via NCS and BCTQ SSS score) was analyzed.

baseline.population: Only the affected wrist was treated in participants with unilateral CTS. Both wrists were treated on participants with bilateral CTS but only the worse wrist (higher severity via NCS or higher BCTQ SSS score) was used for analysis.

group.title: Carpal Tunnel Medical Device (CTMD)
group.description: The Carpal Tunnel Tissue Manipulation Device (CTMD) is a piece of rigid, shaped, biocompatible plastic (polypropylene) rated for skin contact and a strong but safe hypoallergenic biocompatible medical adhesive which bonds the skin over the carpal tunnel to the plastic piece. The CTMD is worn for a duration of 8-10 hours daily over the treatment period. If a participant had bilateral CTS, both wrists were treated but only the worst wrist (via NCS and BCTQ SSS score) was analyzed.

measure.title: Ethnicity (NIH/OMB)
measure.description: The categories for race and ethnicity were combined, such that the Hispanic choice was lumped with Asian, Caucasian, Black, and Other. The single participant that identified as Hispanic was lumped in with Caucasian in the Race section.

measure.title: Race (NIH/OMB)
measure.description: The categories for race and ethnicity were combined, such that the Hispanic choice was lumped with Asian, Caucasian, Black, and Other. The single participant that identified as Hispanic was lumped in with Caucasian in the Race section.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Bilaterality
measure.description: Participants presented with either unilateral CTS (only one wrist affected) or bilateral CTS (both wrists affected).

measure.title: Severity
measure.description: Severity determined using a shortened nerve conduction study protocol and using AANEM criteria.

outcome.title: Change in SSS of the BCTQ at 28 Days vs Baseline
outcome.description: The primary efficacy variable is the decrease in Symptom Severity Scale (SSS) score of the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ). The SSS is a patient-reported measure of the severity of the patient's symptoms caused by carpal tunnel syndrome, on a scale of 1 (no symptoms) to 5 (worst symptoms).
outcome.population: Primary outcome measures were analyzed for unilateral and bilateral subjects combined, but measures were analyzed for unilateral and bilateral subjects separately as well.

group.title: Unilateral+Bilateral
group.description: The CTMD was worn for a duration of 8-10 hours daily over the treatment period. Unilateral subjects wore the CTMD on the single affected wrist. Bilateral subjects wore the CTMD on both wrists, but only the worst wrist (via NCS and BCTQ SSS score) was analyzed.

group.title: Unilateral Only
group.description: The CTMD was worn for a duration of 8-10 hours daily over the treatment period. Unilateral subjects wore the CTMD on the single affected wrist.

group.title: Bilateral Only
group.description: The CTMD was worn for a duration of 8-10 hours daily over the treatment period. Bilateral subjects wore the CTMD on both wrists, but only the worst wrist (via NCS and BCTQ SSS score) was analyzed.

measure.title: Change in SSS of the BCTQ at 28 Days vs Baseline
measure.description: The primary efficacy variable is the decrease in Symptom Severity Scale (SSS) score of the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ). The SSS is a patient-reported measure of the severity of the patient's symptoms caused by carpal tunnel syndrome, on a scale of 1 (no symptoms) to 5 (worst symptoms).
measure.population: Primary outcome measures were analyzed for unilateral and bilateral subjects combined, but measures were analyzed for unilateral and bilateral subjects separately as well.

outcome.title: Change in SSS of the BCTQ 2 Month Post-treatment vs Baseline
outcome.description: The secondary efficacy variable is the decrease in Symptoms Severity Scale (SSS) score of the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ) obtained 2 months after the 28-day CTMD treatment period compared to the Baseline SSS score.

group.title: Unilateral+Bilateral
group.description: The CTMD was worn for a duration of 8-10 hours daily over the treatment period. Unilateral subjects wore the CTMD on the single affected wrist. Bilateral subjects wore the CTMD on both wrists, but only the worst wrist (via NCS and BCTQ SSS score) was analyzed.

group.title: Unilateral Only
group.description: The CTMD was worn for a duration of 8-10 hours daily over the treatment period. Unilateral subjects wore the CTMD on the single affected wrist.

group.title: Bilateral Only
group.description: The CTMD was worn for a duration of 8-10 hours daily over the treatment period. Bilateral subjects wore the CTMD on both wrists, but only the worst wrist (via NCS and BCTQ SSS score) was analyzed.

measure.title: Change in SSS of the BCTQ 2 Month Post-treatment vs Baseline
measure.description: The secondary efficacy variable is the decrease in Symptoms Severity Scale (SSS) score of the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ) obtained 2 months after the 28-day CTMD treatment period compared to the Baseline SSS score.

reported_events.time_frame: 3 months (1 month device wear and 2 months post-treatment) per subject
reported_events.desc: Inclusion of Unanticipated Adverse Device Event (ADE) in addition to SAE, to clarify serious adverse events caused by associated with the device. Adverse events self-reported by subjects and recorded in AE logs.

group.title: Carpal Tunnel Medical Device (CTMD)
group.description: The Carpal Tunnel Tissue Manipulation Device (CTMD) is a piece of rigid, shaped, biocompatible plastic (polypropylene) rated for skin contact and a strong but safe hypoallergenic biocompatible medical adhesive which bonds the skin over the carpal tunnel to the plastic piece. The CTMD is worn for a duration of 8-10 hours daily over the treatment period. If a participant had bilateral CTS, both wrists were treated but only the worst wrist (via NCS and BCTQ SSS score) was analyzed.

event.description: Edge of device pressed into subjects' wrists, causing acute but minor pain
reddening, itching, and minor irritation of skin due to contact with adhesive and pull from device

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: This study was an open-label pilot study with no placebo. Subjects were not allowed other CTS treatments except for occasional painkillers. Daily home activities not controlled. One subject had wrist arthritis. One subject had unconfirmed arthritis.
